THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â 
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Julie D.
      Garcia, Respondent,
				v.
				Matthew D.
      Saski, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Tommy B. Edwards, Family Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-044
Submitted September 18, 2008 â€“ Filed
  November 10, 2008Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Stephen
  K. Haigler, and Michael D. Glenn, both of Glenn, Haigler, McClain &
  Stathakis, of Anderson, for Appellant.
				Julie
  D. Garcia, of Pendleton, pro se Respondent.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General
  Michelle J. Parsons, all of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae. 
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This is a direct appeal from a family court order of protection
  issued June 7, 2006.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Appellant, Matthew Saski, was a patrolman with the Clemson
  University Police Department.Â  Respondent, Julie Garcia was his girlfriend for
  some period of time, and they had planned to get married.Â  They lived together
  for four weeks in April 2006.Â  
According to Garcia, on April 29, 2006, after Saski got home from
  work, they drank some wine, and Garcia went to bed early.Â Â  When Saski came
  into the bedroom around 3:30 a.m., she heard him crying in the shower.Â  He got
  into bed and pointed his middle finger upward toward the ceiling; when she
  asked what he was doing, he said he was praying.Â  She asked him what was wrong
  and he said, â€œIâ€™m the devil, just kill me.â€Â  Saski then told Garcia he had
  killed her dog Angel, saying he had choked her.Â  He put the dogâ€™s body in the
  woods behind the house.Â  According to Garcia, Saski told her, â€œI couldnâ€™t help
  it. Â I couldnâ€™t stop.â€Â  Garcia went and slept in her sonâ€™s bedroom and left
  early the next morning to go to a friendâ€™s house.Â  They corresponded via text
  message that morning, and Garcia asked him to move out.Â  Saski moved out that
  day, and they had no further contact.Â  
Saski presented a different scenario.Â  He testified he was petting
  Angel on the sofa late that night and, as he reached for the remote control, the
  dog went to jump on him, so he pushed her away with his hand.Â  The dog landed
  on the floor and wasnâ€™t moving.Â  He picked her up and attempted to resuscitate
  Angel by blowing into her snout when â€œgreen and brown stuff started coming out.â€Â 
  He took Angel outside and Garciaâ€™s other dog, Charlie, was barking.Â Â Â  He
  realized Angel was dead, so he brought her into the woods so Charlie would stop
  barking.Â  Saski started crying, realizing heâ€™d killed the dog.Â  According to
  Saski, when Garcia asked him what was wrong, he said, â€œAngelâ€™s dead.Â  I think I
  killed her.â€Â  He then told her â€œshe choked,â€ and â€œI couldnâ€™t help her.â€Â  
Several days after the incident, Garcia applied to the family
  court for an order of protection on the basis of the dog incident.Â  After a hearing
  on May 5, 2006, Saski consented to an interim order mutually restricting the
  parties from coming near each other.Â Â  Garcia advised the court at that time
  she did not want Saski to be prevented from returning to his job as a police
  officer.Â  The family court decided to postpone a final ruling until it had the
  benefit of an autopsy report on the dog.Â  
A subsequent hearing was held on June 5, 2006.Â  Although the court
  found the autopsy was not inconsistent with either Garciaâ€™s or Saskiâ€™s version
  of events, the court issued the order of protection based on Garciaâ€™s fear for
  her safety.Â  The order remained in effect for one year.Â  One provision of the
  order, was a Federal Firearms Prohibition, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Â§ 922.Â  
After his motion for rehearing was denied, Saski filed a petition
  for a writ of supersedeas, requesting the June 7, 2006 order of protection be
  stayed, and that the mutual restraining order which had been issued on May 19,
  2006, be allowed to remain in effect pending appeal.Â  Saski contended that
  because the order of protection prevented him from carrying a weapon, he would
  lose his job as a policeman with Clemson University Police Department.Â  His
  captain, James Gowan, filed a supporting affidavit indicating that if the order
  of protection stayed in place as written, Saski stood to lose his job on July
  15, 2006.Â Â  Supersedeas was denied.Â Â  
Saski appeals the order of protection, contending that there was
  no evidence of any abuse, nor the threat thereof, to Garcia.Â Â  We agree.
DISCUSSION[1]
We find the family court erred in issuing the order of protection
  in this case, because the record does not demonstrate Saski posed any threat of
  harm to Garcia or her family.Â  
The S.C. Protection from Domestic Abuse Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-4-20 et seq. permits a family court to issue an order of protection â€œto
  protect the petitioner or minor household members from the abuse of another
  household member.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-20(f).Â  A â€œhousehold memberâ€ is
  defined to include â€œa male and female who are cohabiting or formerly have
  cohabited.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-20(b) (iv).Â Â  Section 20-4-20 permits the
  filing of a petition for an order of protection by any household members in
  need of protection.Â  â€œThe petition must allege the existence of abuse to a
    household member.Â  It must state the specific time, place, details of the
  abuse, and other facts and circumstances upon which relief is sought.â€Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-40(b).Â  â€œAbuseâ€ is defined by the statute as â€œphysical harm,
  bodily injury, assault, or the threat of physical harm,â€ or â€œsexual criminal
  offenses, as otherwise defined by statute, committed against a family or
  household member by a family or household member.â€Â Â  (Emphasis added).Â  
Citing this Courtâ€™s recent opinion in Moore v. Moore,
  376 S.C. 467, 657 S.E.2d 743 (2008), the Attorney General contends it is irrelevant that there was
  no actual, direct threat of harm made by Saski toward Garcia; the AG asserts
  that under Moore, a court need not make a finding of actual abuse of a
  victim in order to issue an order of protection.Â  Our holding in Moore is inapposite.Â Â  
In Moore, a 15-year-old boy called police and reported that
  his father had become physically abusive with him and his mother and threatened
  them with a weapon.Â  The father was arrested and charged with criminal domestic
  violence, then released on bond.Â  The mother petitioned for an order of
  protection, and an emergency hearing was held within 24 hours pursuant to S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-50(a).Â  At the emergency hearing, the family court made a
  final adjudication that the father had physically abused mother and son at that
  hearing.Â  On appeal, when father raised due process implications, this Court
  noted that â€œwe are concerned that a factual finding of physical abuse was
  finally adjudicated at this emergency hearing.â€Â  367 S.C. at 478, 657 S.E.2d at
  749.Â  Due to the emergency nature of the hearing, and the fact that it was held
  within 24 hours prior to the father retaining counsel, we opined:

	[A] definitive factual finding of physical abuse for a temporary
  Order of Protection is not only improper under the terms of the statute, but is
  also unnecessary to satisfy the governmentâ€™s interest. In our view, the
  Legislature provided for an emergency hearing, for the benefit of victims of domestic
  violence and did not intend for these protections to establish collateral
  consequences for the alleged abuser. 

Id.Â  Given the temporary nature of the emergency hearing, the Court
  held â€œ[a] review of these statutory prerequisites reveals that a definitive
  finding of physical abuse is not essential.â€Â  Id. at 480, 657 S.E.2d at
  750.Â  The Court went on to hold that:
[A]lthough the Act defines â€œabuseâ€ to include â€œphysical abuse,â€
  â€œbodily injury,â€ and â€œassault,â€ it also recognizes that â€œthe threat of physical
  harmâ€ is sufficient to constitute a basis for the issuance of an Order of
  Protection as the result of an emergency hearing. S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-20(a)(1)
  (1985 & Supp.2006).Â  We concluded that because the threat of a future
  occurrence is a sufficient basis upon which to issue an order of protection, a
  â€œdefinitive finding of physical abuse is not mandated.â€Â  Id.
The Attorney General asserts â€œthe killing of Angel alone suggested
  an immediate and present danger to [Garciaâ€™s] family,â€ so as to constitute a
  sufficient threat of physical harm.Â  We disagree.
The emergency hearing in this case took place on May 5, 2006,
  approximately one week after the April 29th incident.Â  At that time, the court
  orally determined to issue a temporary mutual restraining order pending a final
  determination after receipt of the autopsy on the dog.Â Â  A subsequent hearing
  was held May 15, 2006, because Saski was not being allowed to work; Garcia
  indicated at this hearing that she did not object to Saski continuing his job.Â 
  At the May 15th hearing, the trial court concurred with counselâ€™s statement
  that Garcia indicated that Saski had not, during the whole sequence of events,
  threatened her in any way or said anything threatening to her.Â Â  However, she
  had indicated that his conduct made her feel threatened.
The final hearing was held June 5, 2006, after the family court
  reviewed the autopsy.Â  The autopsy report was inconclusive, but could not 
rule out blunt
  trauma.Â  The court found Garcia more credible, and found her fear for her
  safety was sufficient to warrant issuance of the order.Â  This was error.Â  
We find Garciaâ€™s subjective fear for her safety does not warrant
  issuance of the order of protection, particularly given the facts that it was
  more than one month between the incident and the final hearing, Saski had moved
  out of the house, and the parties had had absolutely no contact in the
  interim.Â Â  We find the evidence did not demonstrate Saski posed any actual
  threat of physical harm to Garcia or her family. Â Â Accord Kopelovich
    v. Kopelovich, 793 So.2d 31, 33 (Fl. App. 2nd Dist. 2001) (husbandâ€™s threat
  of harm to family dog â€œfailed to establish either immediate or present danger
  or the threat of or actual domestic violence); Fleckner v. Fleckner, ___
  N.E.2d ___, 2008 WL 3198724 (Ohio App. Dist. 2008) (Where husband emailed wife
  he would â€œI will take out all of my anger and frustration in this family
  membersâ€™ death sentence out on wife in court,â€ wifeâ€™s subjective fear was
  insufficient and failed an objective test of reasonableness); Ficklin v.
    Ficklin, 710 N.W.2d 387 (N.D. 2006) (threats may constitute domestic
  violence warranting protection order only if they constitute the infliction of
  fear of imminent physical harm; courtâ€™s findings may not rest solely on
  perceived possibility of domestic violence rather than reasonable fear of
  actual or imminent harm); Moore v. Hall, 786 So.2d 1264 (Fla. App. 2001)
  (former husbandâ€™s statement to process server that he should have killed former
  wife eleven years ago did not provide former wife with objectively reasonable
  fear of imminent domestic violence).Â  
Although Garcia may have subjectively feared Saski, the evidence
  is simply insufficient to demonstrate that he presented any real or imminent
  physical threat to her safety.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order of
  protection is reversed.Â  
REVERSED.
PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a
  separate opinion in which KITTREDGE, J., concurs.

Chief
  Justice Toal:Â  I respectfully
  dissent.Â  In my view, Garciaâ€™s actions posed a threat of physical harm, and I
  would therefore affirm the family courtâ€™s decision.
The evidence in
  this case shows that following the dogâ€™s death, Saski stated that â€œIâ€™m the
  devil, just kill me,â€ â€œI couldnâ€™t help it. I couldnâ€™t stop,â€ and â€œI knew
  something like this was going to happen.â€Â  Additionally, Garcia testified to
  previous incidents with the dog indicating abuse.Â  She noted that on two
  occasions she left the dog alone in the room with Saski and subsequently heard
  the dog â€œyelp.â€Â  Garcia also recalled an incident where she returned home from
  work and found the dog unresponsive and in shock.Â  Garcia stated that Saski
  told her that he found the dog in a drainage ditch and claimed it had been hit
  by a car.Â  Garcia testified that she feared Saski because her son lived in the
  home with her, she believed Saski could not control his actions, and Saski had
  access to a gun. Â Finally, although Garcia and Saski presented different
  accounts of the incident, the family court found Garciaâ€™s version to be more
  credible.
In
  my view, evidence that a household member killed an animal clearly supports a
  finding of a threat of physical harm. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-4-20
  (providing that a family court may issue an order of protection if the petitioner proves the allegation of threat of
  physical harm by a preponderance of the evidence); Moore v. Moore, 376 S.C. 467,478, 657 S.E.2d 743, 749 (2008)
  (holding that a definitive factual finding of physical abuse is
  not required to issue an order of protection).Â  I therefore cannot agree with the majorityâ€™s
  conclusion that this evidence did not show that Saski posed any actual threat
  of physical harm to Garcia or her family, especially in light of the family
  courtâ€™s credibility determination.Â  See Richland County Dept. of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330
  S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1998) (recognizing that because an appellate court lacks the opportunity
  for direct observation of the witness, it should accord great deference to the family courtâ€™s
  findings where matters of credibility are involved).Â  I furthermore believe that the majority errs in
  suggesting that the facts of this case are necessarily comparable to the verbal
  or written threats that family courts in other jurisdictions have ruled did not
  constitute an objectively reasonable fear of domestic violence.Â  While the
  possibility and likelihood of physical harm based on these types of threats can
  vary depending upon many factors, in my view, the malicious and illegal killing
  of a household pet is a direct act of violence posing a threat of physical harm
  to household members.
Our
  legislature drafted the Protection from Domestic Abuse Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-4-10 et seq., to give the family court the authority to issue orders of
  protection against a household member to protect other household members from
  abuse.Â  I believe that the family court in the instant case carefully reviewed
  all of the evidence presented by both sides and correctly issued the order of
  protection.Â  I would therefore affirm the decision.
KITTREDGE,
  J., concurs.


[1]Â  Garcia did not file a respondentâ€™s brief.Â  The
  Attorney General, as amicus curiae, contends the issue is moot as the order on
  appeal expired in June 2007.Â  Given the potential ramifications of the order, we
  find it is not moot.Â  See Moore v. Moore, 376 S.C. 467, 657 S.E.2d 743
  (2008).Â Â  Further, given the orderâ€™s short duration, it is a matter which is
  capable of repetition yet evading review.Â  Byrd v. Irmo High Sch., 321
  S.C. 426, 468 S.E.2d 861 (1996).

PER CURIAM:Â  Â  In this post-conviction relief (PCR) matter, petitioner seeks a
  writ of certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s order dismissing his PCR
  application and finding he is entitled to a belated review of his direct appeal
  issues.Â  
The petition is denied as to petitionerâ€™s Question II.Â  However, because
  there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling that petitioner
  did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we
  grant the petition for a writ of certiorari as to petitionerâ€™s Question I,
  dispense with further briefing, and proceed with a review of the direct appeal
  issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).Â  
Counsel for petitioner has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v.
  California, 386 U.S. 738, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 18 L.Ed.2d 493 (1967) and a
  petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Petitioner has not filed a pro se response.Â  After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Anders, we
  dismiss the appeal and grant the petition to be relieved as counsel.
DISMISSED.

In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Myron Kelley, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
James R. Barber, III, Post-Conviction Relief
  Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2008-MO-047
Submitted November 19, 2008 â€“ Filed
  November 24, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Elizabeth A. Franklin-Best, of the South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General
  John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Brian Petrano, all
  of the Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â 
  In this post-conviction relief (PCR) matter, petitioner seeks a writ of
  certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s order dismissing his PCR application and finding
  he is entitled to a belated review of his direct appeal issues.Â  The State has filed a motion to strike a
  portion of petitionerâ€™s brief.Â  
The
  petition is denied as to petitionerâ€™s Question II.Â  However, because there is
  sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling that petitioner did not
  knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we grant the
  petition for a writ of certiorari as to petitionerâ€™s Question I and proceed
  with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288
  S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).Â  
Petitioner
  contends his guilty plea was not
  knowingly and voluntarily entered because he was unaware that there was a negotiated thirty-year
  sentence.Â  The transcript
  from the plea hearing shows all parties present at the plea hearing â€“
  petitioner, the solicitor, plea counsel, and the plea judge â€“ understood there
  was a thirty-year negotiated sentence.Â  Moreover, petitioner was fully informed
  of the consequences of his guilty plea, including the rights he waived by
  entering a guilty plea and the maximum penalty for his offenses.Â  Roddy v. State, 339 S.C. 29, 528 S.E.2d 418 (2000); Pittman
    v. State, 337 S.C. 597, 524 S.E.2d 623 (1999).Â  Accordingly, we affirm petitionerâ€™s
  convictions and sentences.Â  In light of our disposition of this matter, we deny
  the Stateâ€™s motion as moot.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., not
  participating

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Johnny L.
      Cantrell, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Anderson County
J.C. Nicholson, Trial Judge
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Post-Conviction
  Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-048
Submitted September 18, 2008 â€“ Filed
  November 24, 2008Â Â  
      

REVERSED


	
		
			
				Appellate
  Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
  Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General
  Daniel E. Grigg, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PLEICONES: Â After a jury trial, Petitioner
  Johnny L. Cantrell (Petitioner) was convicted of criminal sexual conduct with a
  minor in the second degree and assault with intent to commit the same.Â 
  Petitioner filed a post-conviction relief (PCR) application alleging
  ineffective assistance of counsel, which the PCR court denied.Â  We reverse. 
FACTS
Defense presented
  Petitionerâ€™s daughter (Daughter) who is also the victimâ€™s sister.Â  Daughter
  testified that she lived in the home during eight of the nine months in which
  the alleged abuse occurred and contradicted much of the victimâ€™s testimony of
  abuse.
The following day,
  the State sought to introduce the testimony of a reply witness (Witness) who,
  during an in-camera hearing, testified that on the day prior to Daughterâ€™s
  testimony, she told Witness that she â€œknewâ€ of her fatherâ€™s guilt.Â  Despite
  repeated inquiries by the trial judge, defense counsel (Counsel) interposed no
  objection to Witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  Witness then testified in court.Â  Counsel
  sought to recall Daughter to deny having made the statement to Witness, but the
  request was denied.
At the PCR hearing,
  Petitioner alleged that Counsel was ineffective in failing to object to
  Witnessâ€™s testimony regarding Daughterâ€™s alleged prior inconsistent statement
  when no proper foundation had been laid.Â  Daughter testified at the hearing and
  denied having made the statement.Â  The PCR judge denied the ineffective
  assistance claim, finding that Counselâ€™s performance was not deficient and that
  Petitioner had not been prejudiced by Witnessâ€™s testimony.

ISSUE
Did the PCR judge
  err in finding that Petitionerâ€™s counsel was not ineffective in failing to
  object to the Stateâ€™s use of a reply witness to impeach a defense witness with
  a prior inconsistent statement without laying a proper foundation?
ANALYSIS
In
  considering a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, courts presume that
  counsel rendered adequate assistance and made all significant decisions in the
  exercise of reasonable professional judgment. Butler v. State,
  286 S.C. 441, 442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985).Â  To receive relief, the
  Petitioner must overcome this presumption by satisfying a two-prong test. Cherry
    v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 117, 386 S.E.2d 624, 625 (1989).Â  We must affirm
  the PCR courtâ€™s ruling if there is any probative evidence to support the
  judgeâ€™s factual findings and conclusions. McCray v. State, 317 S.C. 557,
  559, 455 S.E.2d 686, 687 (1995).Â  Finding no probative evidence to support the
  PCR courtâ€™s finding, we reverse.
A. Deficient Performance
To
  show ineffective assistance of counsel, Petitioner must first prove that trial counselâ€™s
  (Counsel) performance was deficient. Dawkins v. State, 346 S.C. 151,
  155-56, 551 S.E.2d 260, 262 (2001).Â  Under this prong, attorney performance is
  measured by its reasonableness â€œunder prevailing professional norms.â€ Id. 
The
  PCR court found that Counselâ€™s performance was not deficient in failing to
  object to the reply testimony of Witness. Â The PCR court cited two reasons why Counsel
  acted reasonably in not objecting.Â  First, the PCR court noted that Witnessâ€™s
  testimony in reply was proper.Â  Second, Counsel reasonably anticipated being
  able to call Daughter back to the stand in surrebuttal.Â  

(1) Smithâ€™s reply
  testimony was not proper.
Rule
  613(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence (SCRE) provides that extrinsic
  evidence of a prior inconsistent statement is not admissible unless â€œthe
  witness is advised of the substance of the statement, the time and place it was
